thread.title: 'Doomed to fail' man jailed for attacking officer during arrest
thread.title_full: 'Doomed to fail' man jailed for attacking officer during arrest

author: Kristian Silva
title: 'Doomed to fail' man jailed for attacking officer during arrest
text:
Map: Brisbane 4000 
A man who threw a police officer through a glass window during an arrest was "doomed to fail" from birth, his lawyer has said, as a judge sentenced him to five years in prison. 
Morris Steven Mickelo, 32, will serve at least 25 months behind bars before parole over the attack on Senior Constable Reece Jarman at Capalaba in 2014. 
Police were called to Mickelo's property after a domestic disturbance, and when Senior Constable Jarman tried to arrest Mickelo he became violent. 
The court heard he punched him and pushed him through a glass window. 
Senior Constable Samantha Schofield tried to use her Taser to stop Mickelo but it failed, so she fired her gun twice and struck him with both bullets. 'Tough life' leading up to attack 
Mickelo's defence lawyer Mal Harrison said his client was the father of four children and had faced a tough life, where he encountered violence, substance abuse, homelessness and learning difficulties. 
Mickelo suffered lung and liver injuries during the shooting and now had a 30-centimetre scar from surgery, Mr Harrison said. 
"He was born, almost doomed to fail from the date of birth," he said. 
Prosecutor Dejana Kovac said Senior Constable Jarman suffered "daily psychological issues" and had serious arm injuries which still affected him. 
In her victim impact statement, Senior Constable Schofield said the incident left her deeply traumatised. 
"I find it hard to enjoy social activities that I used to find myself interested in," Senior Constable Schofield said during her victim impact statement. 
"Still to this day I have nightmares at least twice a week of my firearm not working or my partner being injured." Officers praised for bravery 
Judge Anthony Rafter said police had behaved "bravely and courageously" while arresting Mickelo. 
"This was lawful force employed by a police officer," he said, regarding the shooting. 
"Police officers serve the community, they perform an important daily function. 
"They were doing their job, they certainly did not deserve to be treated the way that you treated them." 
Mickelo will not be eligible for parole until two years and three months of his sentence has been served.
